summary: Gov. Lamont makes a smart decision to base eligibility on age.. 'I'm going to focus on the old business motto, KISS: Keep it simple, stupid." That's how Connecticut Gov. The more states prioritize social "equity," the more complicated and inequitable vaccine distribution becomes.

title: Puerto Rico Rides Muni-Bond Rally to Bankruptcy Deal
summary: Creditors owed roughly $11.7 billion agreed to settle with Puerto Rico, expecting that its court-supervised bankruptcy is nearing an end. title: Covid-19 Vaccine Success Won't Eliminate Virus Risk, U.K. Concludes
summary: The disease will continue to take a heavy toll even if the shots work, government advisers project. But disease modelers advising the U.K. government recently made a sobering projection: 56,000 more Covid-19 deaths by the summer of next year, even if the country tiptoes out of lockdown and the vaccines work.

summary: Treasury prices rally, but traders worry about a reversal if inflation picks up. title: 'Punky Brewster' Review: The '80s Foster Kid Is Now a Mom
summary: Soleil Moon Frye reprises her role in a reboot of the boundary-breaking sitcom.. 'Punky Brewster," the "Punky-Powered" sitcom of the mid-'80s starring the bubbly Soleil Moon Frye, had a relatively brief life on NBC, another in syndication and was the inspiration for a Saturday morning cartoon. The very phrase "Saturday morning cartoon" summons up the kind of nostalgia that Peacock's rebooted "Punky Brewster" is intended to kindle. Rather than the fragrant recycling effort it actually suggests.

title: Lack of Accountability and Mediocrity Are Partners
summary: There is continuing pressure to reduce or eliminate accountability throughout our society.. As I read the quote in John F. Cogan and John B. Taylor's "What George Shultz Taught Us About Making Policy" (op-ed, Feb. 10) regarding the importance of accountability, I was reminded of Andy Kessler's "Mediocrity Is Now Mandatory" (Inside View, Feb. 8). One can describe all of his examples of rising mediocrity as consequences of diminished accountability. Outside of government and academia, as Mr. Kessler points out, it isn't possible to avoid accountability forever, and its salutary effects are eventually manifested in improved individual and institutional performance. However, it seems that there is continuing pressure to reduce or eliminate accountability throughout our society-witness the ever-increasing suppression, cheered on by many journalists, of dissenting views on such issues as climate change, race or transgenderism, no matter how factually well supported and carefully and compassionately presented, or the spread of the toxic antiaccountability critical race theory through our institutions. Individual accountability and basing one's arguments on facts that can be verified by others are the foundation of a successful society. Unless the leaders of our institutions grow spines and reassert such values, mediocrity will indeed become the new normal.

title: Beat Poet, Publisher Lawrence Ferlinghetti Dies at 101
summary: Ferlinghetti was known for his City Lights bookstore in San Francisco, a meeting place for the Beats and other bohemians in the 1950s and beyond. SAN FRANCISCO-Poet, publisher and bookseller Lawrence Ferlinghetti, who helped launch and perpetuate the Beat movement, has died. He was 101.

title: Embrace Yourself (Wednesday Crossword, February 24)
Deaths From Texas Storm Could Take Months to Tally
summary: Officials are still counting fatalities from hypothermia, carbon monoxide, other factors as some experts warn accurate total might never be known. The harsh winter storm that hit Texas and other states last week has been blamed for dozens of deaths, though officials said that it would be weeks or months before the human cost of the freezing weather and utility crisis is known and that it might never be fully accurate.

title: Fed's Powell Sees Easy-Money Policies Staying in Place
summary: Fed likely to hold interest rates near zero and continue asset purchases for some time, chairman says. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reaffirmed the central bank's commitment to maintaining easy-money policies until the economy has recovered further from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Multiple Power Sources Fail and Texas Freezes
summary: Here in Michigan, we have more than a thousand wind turbines that operate without failures in far more severe winter weather than Texas has ever seen.. Your editorial "Texas Spins Into the Wind" (Feb. 18) misplaces the blame for the rolling blackouts in Texas on its "frozen turbines." Here in Michigan, we have more than a thousand wind turbines that operate without failure in far more severe winter weather than Texas has ever seen. The difference is that our wind turbines are equipped with optional cold-weather packages; apparently the turbines in Texas are not. This is an extra-cost option that wind-turbine manufacturers offer, just as auto makers offer optional cold-weather packages for the cars they sell. Michigan gas pipelines and power plants are also winterized, and continue to operate in severe weather. It isn't the fault of wind-turbine technology that some of the wind turbines in Texas froze; it was the result of a cost-cutting purchase decision that backfired.

title: What Is an FSA and How Does It Work?
summary: Most Popular News. If you are starting a new job or going through open enrollment, you might see an option to open an FSA. While it makes sense for some people to put aside money pretax to spend on qualified expenses, the accounts aren't right for everyone.

title: Biden's Many Policies Often Seem to Conflict
summary: Walter Russell Mead is correct in his assessment of President Biden's early policy instincts being a return to Obama objectives and strategies. Unfortunately the Obama path rarely achieved the stated results.. Walter Russell Mead is correct in his assessment of President Biden's early policy instincts being a return to Obama objectives and strategies ("The Antidote to Trump Isn't Obama Redux," Global View, Feb. 9). Unfortunately the Obama path rarely achieved the stated results. What comes to mind is the contradiction between President Biden's pronounced priorities and the real-world impact of his early achievements, such as they are.

summary: Raytheon's Pratt & Whitney unit made the problem engine that caused a United flight to make an emergency landing after showering debris over parts of Colorado. title: Image, Feeling Good and the $15 Minimum Wage
summary: In the Navy, we had an adage: "An ounce of image is worth a pound of performance.". In "The Minimum Wage's Racially Discriminatory Roots" (Upward Mobility, Feb. 17), Jason Riley cites a new Congressional Budget Office report, a 2014 analysis by Joseph Sabia and Richard Burkhauser and a labor study by Willian Even and David Macpherson from 2007-09; all of which unequivocally conclude that many low-skilled workers would be displaced if the federal minimum wage were set at $15. In the Navy, we had an adage: "An ounce of image is worth a pound of performance."

title: 'Age of Samurai: Battle for Japan' Review: Feuding Lords and Their Fighters
summary: In Netflix's six-part documentary, historian interviews and bloody re-enactments tell the story of the country's civil war. The ostensible subjects of "Age of Samurai: Battle for Japan" are dubbed "the mounted knights of old Japan" and while a properly romantic description, it falls a bit short: The sword-wielding martial artists of the feudal era (1185-1868) have not only taken up residence in the Western imagination but created ornate, interlacing connections between pop cultures East and West. Akira Kurosawa, for instance, who was a student of John Ford, portrayed his heroes like the gunslingers of the Old West, or even Prohibition gangsters. Detective novelist Dashiell Hammett's 1929 "Red Harvest" was the basis for Kurosawa's "Yojimbo," which in turn inspired Sergio Leone's "A Fistful of Dollars," which inspired the Bruce Willis movie "Last Man Standing." Beneath all the intersecting fictional mayhem lay feudal roots. Most of us samurai-movie fans just don't know where or what they are.

title: Sweatpants Are Not Peak Comfort-Fleece Trousers Are
summary: Men whose style skews casual are zeroing in on the coziest things around: outrageously soft fleece trousers. IF YOU BELIEVE that shlumpy, elastic-waisted sweatpants sit at the extreme end of casual wear, well, you are wrong. Push further into the realm of comfort and you will find fuzzy fleece pants, perhaps the most notable achievement in wearable coziness. Cut like a roomy sweatpant (often with a similarly accommodating elastic waist) but fabricated in a highly insulating plush material, fleece pants are like a Patagonia Retro-X jacket transplanted onto your legs. Could it get any cozier than that?

title: The World Health Organization Must Be Made to Change
summary: The world failed to reform the WHO after SARS. Repeating that mistake would be diplomatic malpractice.. Regarding your editorial "Who Are the Covid Investigators?" (Feb. 15): Covid-19 has exposed major deficiencies throughout the World Health Organization (WHO), as well as the dangers of leaving China's U.N. activism unchecked. The Covid-19 response also shares many parallels with SARS, including unexplained WHO delays in declaring both outbreaks; China's refusal to provide accurate, timely data; and Beijing's reliance on misinformation to deflect culpability. Amplifying these challenges are structural, governance and prioritization challenges throughout the WHO's bureaucracy.

title: Overthinking Cruise Stocks Could End the Carnival

But markets' new mantra seems to channel the age-old design principle: "Keep it simple, stupid."

title: China's Reckless Labs Put the World at Risk
summary: Beijing is obsessed with viruses, but not biosafety. We are paying a high price for its lapses.. The Chinese Communist Party is obsessed with viruses. Its army of scientists claim to have discovered almost 2,000 new viruses in a little over a decade. It took the past 200 years for the rest of the world to discover that many. More troubling is the party's negligence on biosafety. The costs and the risk to world health are enormous, as evidenced by a novel coronavirus that escaped Wuhan. This situation can't continue. The world must hold the Chinese Communist Party accountable and punish Beijing if it fails to uphold global biosafety standards, including basic transparency requirements.

title: Is Your Workout Age-Appropriate?
summary: Gyrating along to a baby-faced trainer with thumping music in a glowing pink cube? Where to go instead for sweat, empowerment, Beyoncé-approved catharsis-and above all, your dignity. Coming on the one-year anniversary of life inside a bell jar, I squinted into my laptop and watched a woman undulate and flick her hair to the dancehall-inflected sounds of Doja Cat. "One, two, three, four; one, two, three, four! Body rooolllll, and booty, booty!" Dressed in chalk-blue pajama shorts and a long-sleeved black bodysuit, my virtual trainer Emily Diers fell somewhere on the spectrum between Doris Day and Jane Fonda. My 43-year-old body, a decade older than hers, was clad in nothing but a T-shirt and cotton underpants. I couldn't help but take a video of the you've-got-to-be-kidding-me choreography to send to my best friend. "I'm doing these moves, in my own tragic way," I wrote in a state of energized disbelief. I pressed send, and then I got back to it.

title: Private Equity May Face Attention-Getting SEC Fines Under Gensler
summary: Chairman-Designate Gary Gensler is expected to be tougher on investment firms. The largest U.S. financial regulator has turned its focus away from private equity in recent years, but new agency leadership could mean tougher enforcement and heavier fines for buyout firms, attorneys and lobbyists say.

title: DoorDash Investors Should Relish Their Feast
summary: Coming fourth-quarter results may mark the peak of investor appetite. DoorDash is a newly minted $65 billion public food-delivery company trading near its highs just as the coronavirus is beginning to wane and restaurants are opening back up. What could possibly go wrong?

title: To Make More Covid-19 Vaccines, Rival Drugmakers Team Up
summary: Sanofi and Novartis are among the big pharmaceutical companies that have agreed to help make a competitor's shots. Some of the world's biggest drugmakers are joining forces with rivals to help produce Covid-19 vaccines, forging unusual alliances that promise to substantially increase supplies by this summer.

title: China's Robinhoods are Doing Just Fine, Thanks
summary: The GameStop frenzy created problems for U.S. online brokers, but brokers helping Chinese people punt on U.S. stocks are doing well. In a gold rush, sell shovels. In a U.S. stock-trading mania, be an online broker-a Chinese one, that is.

title: For Stocks, This Bond Selloff Isn't Like the Others
summary: The latest market gyrations are being driven by "real" rates rather than simply by inflation expectations. Investors may need to reassess their portfolios.. Bonds are selling off again, but for different reasons. Investors also need to behave differently.

title: VidMob, a Software Firm for Advertising Creative Data and Services, Raises $50 Million
summary: Investors in funding round include ad industry veterans, Adobe, Shutterstock and Prefix Capital. VidMob Inc., a software firm that provides tools and services for marketers to create and improve their digital advertising, has closed a Series C funding round for $50 million as it targets new business growth in areas such as e-commerce.

title: Spotify Needs to Sing Every Tune
summary: Music-streaming giant's new ventures in podcasting, advertising and artist promotion have a high bar, as valuation has surged. Spotify sees itself as much more than a music-streaming platform. Investors have long since gotten there.

title: Twitter's High Hopes for India Waver Under Government's Heavy Hand
summary: Social-media company's relationship with New Delhi gets rockier as the latter increases demands to block users. As Twitter Inc. looks overseas for growth, India stands out as its fastest-growing major market, one filled with opportunity-and increasingly thorny political challenges.

title: Hotel Sellers Use Car-Sales Model to Finance Lodging Deals
summary: Banks, owners offer cheap rates and sometimes require little money down to unload unprofitable hotels. The lodging industry is under such stress that some property sellers are willing to lend to prospective hotel buyers the way auto dealers finance vehicle sales: Offer cheap rates and sometimes with little money down.

title: Companies Put the Best Face on Covid-19's Financial Impact
summary: Potentially misleading disclosures related to the pandemic attract closer scrutiny from regulators. After its business was hit by the pandemic, retailer Ulta Beauty Inc. appears to have used some accounting cosmetics to add a gloss to its financial results.

title: Becerra Faces Tough Confirmation Hearing to Lead HHS
summary: The California attorney general and longtime House member is opposed by Republicans as overly liberal, lacking in public-health experience. California Attorney General Xavier Becerra is expected to face a tough confirmation hearing Tuesday as Republicans are set to argue that President Biden's pick for Health and Human Services secretary is overly liberal and lacks public-health experience.

title: Lawmakers Call for Ambassador to Represent U.S. in Cyberspace
summary: Bill proposing update to Cyber Diplomacy Act would create State Department office to lead cyber strategy. A group of congressional lawmakers is renewing its call for a cyber ambassador in the State Department, reviving a bill that created friction between Congress and the Trump administration.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Schemes Grow, Leveraging Confusion About How to Get the Shot
summary: U.S. authorities arrested three men in connection with a fake website purporting to sell doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine. Consumers researching ways to protect against the novel coronavirus might have stumbled upon what appeared to be a new website from Moderna Inc., announcing in capital letters, "You may be able to buy a Covid-19 vaccine ahead of time," and offering doses for $30 each.

title: SPACs Face New Test: A Wave of Asia-Focused Deals
summary: Tycoons in the region put money into U.S. blank-check companies as major local stock exchanges haven't allowed such listings. Thousands of miles from Wall Street, the boom in blank-check companies is taking hold in a region where major stock exchanges don't let firms raise money for unspecified uses.

title: Facebook Reverses Australia News Ban
summary: Government to make changes to legislation, including requiring more negotiation before binding arbitration kicks in. SYDNEY-Facebook Inc. reached a deal with the Australian government to restore news pages to the social media company's platform, following a five-day suspension because of a disagreement over payment for content.

title: Wife of 'El Chapo' Is Arrested in U.S. on Drug Charges
summary: Emma Coronel was arrested for allegedly helping her husband, Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán, run his drug empire. MEXICO CITY-The U.S.-born wife of imprisoned drug lordJoaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán was arrested Monday for allegedly helping her husband run his drug empire and carry out an escape from a maximum-security Mexican prison, the U.S. Justice Department said.

title: Boeing 777 Engines Made by Pratt & Whitney Already Faced New Scrutiny
summary: Metal fatigue found in damaged engine of United Airlines jet involved in latest incident over the weekend. U.S. air-safety regulators were considering whether to mandate increased inspections of certain Pratt & Whitney engines before one powering a United Airlines Holdings Inc. flight broke apart Saturday over a town near Denver, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Public Employee Unions Serve Despite Covid
summary: Bemoaning modest raises for state employees, Carol Platt Liebau attempts to divide and conquer.. Bemoaning modest raises for state employees, Carol Platt Liebau attempts to divide and conquer so that ultrawealthy individuals can continue to enjoy lower effective tax rates than working-poor and middle-class families ("Public Employee Unions Are Having a Fine Old Lockdown," Cross Country, Feb. 13). Pitting private- and public-sector workers against each other, Ms. Liebau deflects attention from the affluent interests: the multimillionaires and billionaires whose net worth soared in recent months.

title: Massive Protests Sweep Myanmar During Strike to Oppose Coup
summary: Resume Subscription. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets across Myanmar in response to calls by activists for a general strike, mounting what appeared to be one of the largest demonstrations against this month's coup and signaling to the country's military that resistance to its takeover isn't likely to abate.

title: Lucid Motors Set to Go Public in SPAC Deal
summary: Electric-vehicle company plans to begin deliveries of its first car later this year. Fledgling electric vehicle company Lucid Motors Inc. has agreed to go public by merging with special-purpose acquisition company Churchill Capital Corp IV in one of the largest ever deals involving a SPAC, the companies said Monday.

title: Rheumatoid Arthritis Drug Shows Promise in Fighting Covid-19
summary: A new study shows an anti-inflammatory drug can help treat certain severe symptoms of Covid-19, and adds a tool for helping the sickest patients. An anti-inflammatory drug can help reduce the risk of death in people hospitalized with Covid-19, a new clinical trial indicates, reviving hopes-and debate-about a medicine that many physicians had abandoned after earlier clinical-trial failures.

title: Biden Remembers the 500,000 Covid-19 Victims
summary: U.S. deaths from the virus surpassed half a million nearly a year after a world-wide pandemic was declared. WASHINGTON-With a moment of silence and a candlelit memorial, President Biden marked the loss of life from Covid-19, as the U.S. death toll passed 500,000 Monday.

title: Treasury May Be Able to Facilitate Climate Stress Tests
summary: Janet Yellen says at conference that tests likely wouldn't impose capital requirements or limit dividend payouts. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Treasury may be able to facilitate climate stress tests on U.S. banks and insurers, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said Monday, though the tests likely wouldn't impose capital requirements or limit dividend payouts as existing stress tests do.

title: Two Swing Republicans to Oppose Biden's Pick to Lead Budget Office
summary: Pathway for Biden's pick to head Office of Management and Budget narrows after Sens. Romney and Collins come out against her. WASHINGTON-President Biden's pick to lead the White House budget office was in deeper peril Monday after two swing Republican senators said they would vote against her, underscoring the power of centrist lawmakers in the closely divided Senate.

title: Families of Pensacola Terror Attack Victims Sue Saudi Arabia
summary: Complaint asks the court to find that the Gulf kingdom is liable and seeks damages. WASHINGTON-The families of three service members killed and 13 others injured in a shooting at Naval Air Station Pensacola in 2019 sued Saudi Arabia, alleging that the Gulf kingdom should have known the gunman, a member of the Saudi air force, was a threat.

title: 'Mick the Miner' Looks to Recharge With Battery Metals
summary: One of the mining industry's most prolific dealmakers, Mick Davis has set up a new fund to invest in metals required to store power. One of mining's heavyweights is betting on batteries to power his comeback.
